topics.title: Introduction to C++
topics.description: History of C++
extra: C++ was developed by Bjarne Stroustrup at AT&T Bell Laboratories (Murray Hill, New Jersey) in 1979.
It was originally called 'C with Classes', because it extended the C language by adding object-oriented features.
C++ is a cross-platform language that can be used to create high-performance applications.
"C++ is a superset of C programming with additional implementation of object-oriented concepts".
C++ is an important programming language for students and working professionals to become great software developers.

C++ programming gives you a clear understanding of object-oriented programming. You will understand low level implementation of polymorphism when you implement virtual tables and virtual table pointers, or dynamic type identification.
C++ really teaches you the difference between compiler, linker, and loader, different data types, storage classes, variable types, their scopes, etc.

topics.title: Features of C++
topics.description: Key features and strengths of C++.
extra: C Language Compatibility: C++ is an extension of C (originally called C with Classes). Almost all valid C code can be compiled and executed in C++. Functions, arrays, pointers, and printf()/scanf() from C can also be used in C++.
Object-oriented Programming: C++ supports the concepts of OOPs such as objects & classes, encapsulation, data binding, inheritance, and polymorphism.
Classes & Objects → blueprint & actual entity.
Encapsulation → wrapping data and functions together.
Data Binding → restricting direct access to data (using private/public).
Inheritance → creating new classes from existing ones.
Polymorphism → one function behaving differently in different contexts.

Compiled Language: C++ is a compiled language, meaning the source code is converted into machine code by a compiler (like g++ or clang++). This makes it faster than interpreted languages (like Python or JavaScript) where code is executed line-by-line. Because of compilation, C++ is widely used in game engines, operating systems, real-time systems, and embedded systems.
Standard Template Library (STL): STL is a collection of pre-built classes and functions for common data structures and algorithms. Saves time since you don’t have to write everything from scratch.
Containers → Data structures like vector, list, map, set.
Iterators → Used to access elements of containers.
Algorithms → Predefined functions like sort(), find(), reverse().

Dynamic Memory Management: In C++, memory can be allocated at runtime using the new operator and released using the delete operator. This makes programs flexible and allows them to use memory efficiently.
Exception Handling: Errors can happen during runtime (like dividing by zero, invalid input, etc.). In C, handling such errors is difficult. In C++, we use try, catch, throw for safe error handling.

topics.title: Structure of a C++ Program
topics.description: General structure and flow of a C++ program.

examples.output: This is the structure of a C++ program!

extra: Preprocessor Directive (#include): Tells the compiler to include header files before compilation.
Namespace (using namespace std;): Defines a scope to avoid naming conflicts.
Main Function (int main()): Entry point of every C++ program. Program execution starts here. Must return an integer (usually 0 for successful execution).
Statements & Expressions: The body of the program, enclosed in { }.
Return Statement (return 0;): Ends the program and returns control to the operating system.

topics.title: Compiling and Running C++ Programs
topics.description: Compilation process for C++ source code into an executable.
extra: Source Code (.cpp): What you write.
Preprocessor: Prepares the recipe (expands macros & includes).
Compiler: Translates into Assembly (syntax check, semantic check, optimization, assembly generation).
Assembly Code (.s): Human-readable machine instructions.
Assembler: Converts to binary (machine code).
Object File (.o / .obj): Incomplete piece of the program.
Linker: Combines everything (libraries + your code).
Executable Program (.exe / a.out): Final runnable program.

topics.title: Basics of C++
topics.description: C++ basic syntax and structure.
extra: Syntax in C++ defines the rules for writing code.
If we don’t follow these rules, the compiler will give errors.
They can also be viewed as the grammatical rules defining the structure of a programming language.
The C++ language has its own syntax for the functionalities it provides.
The program structure contains header files, main function, namespace declaration, and statements.

topics.title: Tokens in C++
topics.description: Smallest element in a C++ program meaningful to the compiler.
extra: Keywords: Reserved words with special meaning (cannot be used as identifiers).
Examples: int, float, return, while, class, public, if, else, switch, for, void.
Identifiers: Names given to variables, functions, classes, objects, arrays, etc.
Rules: Must begin with a letter or underscore, case-sensitive, cannot use keywords.
Constants: Fixed values that do not change (integer, float, char, string, boolean).
Variables: Named memory storage, value can change during program execution.
Operators: Symbols that perform operations on variables and values.
Punctuators: Symbols like ; , { } ( ) [ ] : used to structure a program.

topics.title: Data Types in C++
topics.description: Different kinds of data supported by C++ with associated memory requirements.
extra: Primitive Types: char, int, bool, float, double.
Derived Types: Function, Array, Pointer, Reference.
User-defined Types: Class, Structure, Union, typedef.
char → stores a single character (1 byte).
int → whole numbers (4 bytes).
bool → true/false (1 byte).
float → single precision decimal (4 bytes).
double → double precision decimal (8 bytes).
Function → reusable block of code with return type.
Array → contiguous block of same data type.
Pointer → stores memory address of a variable.
Reference → alias of another variable.
Class → blueprint for objects with methods and attributes.
Structure → groups multiple variables.
Union → stores one member at a time (shared memory).
typedef → creates an alias name for a type.

topics.title: Variables in C++
topics.description: A variable is a name given to a memory location that stores a value.

examples.explanation: Examples of valid variable declarations in C++.

extra: Start with a letter or underscore (_).
Can contain letters, digits, and underscores.
Cannot use C++ keywords (reserved words).
Case-sensitive (num and Num are different).
No spaces or special characters except underscore (_).

topics.title: Constants in C++
topics.description: A constant is a variable whose value cannot be changed once initialized.

examples.explanation: num is declared constant and cannot be reassigned.

extra: Declared using the const keyword.
Readability: Names like PI, MAX_SIZE are easier to understand.
Maintainability: Change value in one place only.
Safety: Prevents accidental modification.
Performance: Compiler can optimize constants better.

topics.description: Type Casting means converting one data type into another.

examples.explanation: Explicit type casting int → float.

extra: Implicit Type Casting: Done automatically by compiler (e.g., int promoted to double).
Explicit Type Casting: Done manually by programmer (e.g., (int)pi).

topics.title: Operators in C++
topics.description: Operators perform operations on variables and values.

examples.explanation: Arithmetic operators in action.

extra: Arithmetic Operators: +, -, *, /, %, ++, --
Relational Operators: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=
Logical Operators: &&, ||, !
Assignment Operators: =, +=, -=, *=, /=
Ternary Operator: ? :

topics.title: Control Structures in C++
topics.description: Control structures define the flow of execution in a program.
extra: Types of control structures include decision-making, looping, and jump statements.
They decide which block of code executes, how many times, and in what order.

topics.title: Decision Making in C++
topics.description: Used to execute code based on conditions.

examples.explanation: if executes when condition is true.
if-else executes one of two blocks.
Nested if for multiple conditions.
switch selects among multiple cases.

extra: if → executes block if condition is true.
if-else → executes either if or else block.
Nested if → an if inside another if.
switch → selects one case based on a value.
Case values must be int or char type.
Break prevents fall-through in switch.
Default executes if no case matches.

topics.title: Loops in C++
topics.description: Loops execute a block of code repeatedly until a condition is met.

examples.explanation: for loop executes a fixed number of times.
while loop executes while condition is true.
do-while executes at least once.

extra: for loop → entry-controlled, executes fixed times.
while loop → entry-controlled, condition checked before body.
do-while loop → exit-controlled, executes body at least once.

topics.title: Jump Statements in C++
topics.description: Used to change the normal flow of execution.

examples.explanation: break exits the loop.
continue skips the current iteration.
goto jumps to a labeled statement.

extra: break → exits loop or switch immediately.
continue → skips current iteration, continues loop.
goto → transfers control to a labeled statement.
return → exits from a function and returns control to caller.

topics.title: Functions in C++
topics.description: A function is a block of code that performs a specific task and can be reused.

examples.explanation: Function declaration, definition, and call.

extra: Function Declaration → specifies function name, return type, parameters.
Function Definition → contains actual code inside { }.
Function Call → invokes the function from main().
Return Type → type of value function returns (int, float, void).
Arguments/Parameters → input values to the function.

topics.title: Arguments in C++ Functions
topics.description: Parameters can be passed by value, by reference, or with default values.

examples.explanation: Demonstrates default arguments.

extra: Pass by Value → copy of argument is passed.
Pass by Reference → reference (&) passed, changes affect original.
Default Arguments → parameters with default values if not provided.

topics.title: Inline Functions in C++
topics.description: Inline functions expand in place to reduce function call overhead.

examples.explanation: Compiler may replace function call with body.

extra: Reduces function call overhead.
May increase code size if used excessively.
Best for small, frequently used functions.

topics.title: Function Overloading in C++
topics.description: Two or more functions can have the same name but different parameter lists.

examples.explanation: Compiler chooses function based on arguments.

extra: Overloaded functions must differ in number/type of parameters.
Cannot overload by return type only.

topics.title: Recursion in C++
topics.description: A function that calls itself directly or indirectly.

examples.explanation: Factorial implemented using recursion.

extra: Base case is required to stop recursion.
Recursive calls use stack memory.
Useful for problems like factorial, Fibonacci, tree traversal.

topics.title: Storage Classes in C++
topics.description: Define scope, visibility, and lifetime of variables.
extra: auto → default for local variables, automatic storage.
register → request to store variable in CPU register.
static → preserves value across function calls.
extern → refers to global variable declared elsewhere.
mutable → allows modification of class member even in const object.

topics.title: Arrays in C++
topics.description: An array is a collection of elements of the same type stored in contiguous memory locations.

examples.explanation: Demonstrates declaration, initialization, and traversal of array.

extra: Single-dimensional arrays store elements in one row.
Multi-dimensional arrays store elements in rows and columns.
Array index starts from 0.
Arrays have fixed size.

topics.title: Strings in C++
topics.description: A string is a sequence of characters, stored as an array of char or as std::string class.

examples.explanation: Using std::string class.

extra: C-style strings: char str[] = "Hello";
std::string is preferred for modern C++.
Functions include length(), append(), compare(), substr().

topics.title: Pointers in C++
topics.description: A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of another variable.

examples.explanation: Pointer stores address, * dereferences it.

extra: Pointer declaration: int *ptr;
Address-of operator (&) gives variable’s address.
Dereference operator (*) accesses value at address.
NULL pointer points to nothing.
Pointers enable dynamic memory allocation.

topics.title: Structures in C++
topics.description: A structure is a user-defined data type that groups different data types under one name.

examples.explanation: Structure groups different types together.

extra: Defined using struct keyword.
Can contain variables of different data types.
Members are accessed using dot operator.
Structures support nesting and arrays of structures.

topics.title: Enumerations in C++
topics.description: An enum is a user-defined type consisting of a set of named integral constants.

examples.explanation: Enumeration constants are integers starting from 0.

extra: Default values start from 0 and increase by 1.

topics.title: Typedef in C++
topics.description: typedef gives a new name (alias) to an existing data type.

examples.explanation: uint is an alias for unsigned int.

extra: Simplifies complex declarations.
Improves code readability.

topics.title: References in C++
topics.description: A reference is an alias for another variable.

examples.explanation: ref is another name for a.

extra: Reference must be initialized when declared.

topics.title: Object-Oriented Programming in C++
topics.description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects that contain data and functions.
extra: OOP focuses on objects rather than functions.
Supports modularity and code reusability.
Core concepts: Class, Object, Inheritance, Polymorphism, Abstraction, Encapsulation.

topics.title: Classes and Objects in C++
topics.description: A class is a blueprint for objects. Objects are instances of a class.

examples.explanation: Defines a class and creates an object.

extra: class keyword defines a class.
Objects are created from classes.

topics.title: Constructors in C++

examples.explanation: Parameterized constructor initializes object with values.

extra: Constructor has same name as class.
No return type, not even void.

examples.explanation: Destructor is called when object goes out of scope.

topics.title: Encapsulation in C++
topics.description: Encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods operating on that data within one unit.

examples.explanation: Encapsulation hides data using private members.

extra: Data members are private.
Access is controlled via public getter/setter methods.
Provides data hiding and security.

topics.title: Inheritance in C++
topics.description: Inheritance allows one class to acquire properties and behavior of another class.

examples.explanation: Child inherits from Parent.

extra: Base class → parent class being inherited from.
Derived class → child class that inherits.
Types: Single, Multiple, Multilevel, Hierarchical, Hybrid Inheritance.
Inheritance improves code reusability.

topics.title: Polymorphism in C++
topics.description: Polymorphism allows one function or operator to behave differently based on context.

examples.explanation: Runtime polymorphism with virtual functions.

extra: Compile-time polymorphism → function overloading, operator overloading.
Runtime polymorphism → achieved via virtual functions.
Base class pointers can call derived class methods.

topics.title: Abstraction in C++
topics.description: Abstraction hides implementation details and shows only essential features.

examples.explanation: Abstract class with pure virtual function.

extra: Achieved using abstract classes and interfaces.

topics.title: Friend Functions in C++
topics.description: A friend function is not a member of a class but has access to its private and protected members.

throw keyword generates exception.
catch block handles the exception.

ifstream → input file stream (reading).

examples.explanation: PI replaced by 3.14 before compilation.

topics.title: Standard Template Library (STL) in C++
topics.description: STL is a library of template classes and functions for data structures and algorithms.

examples.explanation: STL sort function used on vector.

Algorithms → sort(), find(), reverse(), accumulate().
Iterators → used to traverse containers.
STL makes C++ powerful and reusable.

topics.title: Summary of C++
topics.description: C++ is a powerful, compiled, object-oriented language widely used for system and application development.
extra: Combines low-level (close to hardware) and high-level (OOP) features.
Used in operating systems, game engines, browsers, databases, embedded systems.
Supports modularity, reusability, performance.
Foundation for advanced languages like Java and C#.
